bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August [17], 1942

div1.p: Kean sends Hench a copy of a letter Truby had sent to him regarding the introduction to the memoir he is writing.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August [17], 1942
div1.opener:
Truby
letter in
Truby file
2804 N Street
Washington DC.
Aug. 17/42
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Here is a fine letter which I have
just received from General Truby
which has several things in it which
I am sure will interest you, as
you took so much interest in his
Memoir. He asked me to write an
introduction to it a month or two ago
but between being sick in May & June
and the terrible humid heat in July
I did not feel up to it. I wrote to
Mrs. Truby (he was away) that I would
put pen to paper the first day in
August that the max. fell to 83° F
A cool east wind came on the 4thand
on the 5th the max was 73° F so I did
so, and as you see from this letter
Truby is well satisfied when I get
the carbon copy I will send it to you
as you are in it too. I had a fine
call from Mr. Kellogg who said he
was going to Fort Custer to see you.

Please return Truby's letter after
reading, with a line or two to tell
me how the Army is treating you.

closer.seg:
Let me know what rank they gave
you. I think I addressed you as
major before, but I think you
should have a grade higher, so
I will give it to you
